DataElement.preferredName: Chronic Graft Versus Host Disease Gastrointestinal Tract Involvement NIH Consensus Response Criteria for cGVHD Severity Score
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Information related to the NIH Consensus Response Criteria for cGVHD severity of gastrointestinal tract involvement.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Chronic Graft Versus Host Disease Gastrointestinal Tract Involvement
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A syndrome of immunologically mediated tissue damage that may occur following an allogeneic transplant, and may affect multiple organs with manifestations similar to autoimmune diseases. The onset is usually within three years of transplantation or immunologic manipulation._The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff._To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Chronic Graft Versus Host Disease Gastrointestinal Tract
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A syndrome of immunologically mediated tissue damage that may occur following an allogeneic transplant, and may affect multiple organs with manifestations similar to autoimmune diseases. The onset is usually within three years of transplantation or immunologic manipulation.:The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff.

Concepts.definition: A syndrome of immunologically mediated tissue damage that may occur following an allogeneic transplant, and may affect multiple organs with manifestations similar to autoimmune diseases. The onset is usually within three years of transplantation or immunologic manipulation.

The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff.

Property.preferredDefinition: To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.

Concepts.definition: To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Gastrointestinal Tract NIH Consensus Response Criteria for cGVHD Severity Score
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff._A tool used to assess response to therapy for chronic Graft versus Host Disease (cGVHD) based on clinical trial findings and recommended by the NIH Chronic Graft-versus-Host Disease Consensus Response Criteria Working Group. The criteria were established in 2005 (Biol Blood Marrow Transplant, 12 (2006), pp. 252-266) and revised in 2014 (Biol Blood Marrow Transplant, 21 (2015), pp. 984-999)._Used of the degree of something undesirable e.g. pain or weather; also, strictness._A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Symptoms associated with significant weight loss (greater than15 percent), requires nutritional supplementation for most calorie needs OR esophageal dilation OR severe diarrhea with significant interference with daily living

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Symptoms associated with significant weight loss (greater than15 percent), requires nutritional supplementation for most calorie needs OR esophageal dilation OR severe diarrhea with significant interference with daily living
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Symptoms associated with significant weight loss (greater than15 percent), requires nutritional supplementation for most calorie needs OR esophageal dilation OR severe diarrhea with significant interference with daily living

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Symptoms associated with mild to moderate weight loss (5-15 percent) OR moderate diarrhea without significant interference with daily living

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Symptoms associated with mild to moderate weight loss (5-15 percent) OR moderate diarrhea without significant interference with daily living
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Symptoms associated with mild to moderate weight loss (5-15 percent) OR moderate diarrhea without significant interference with daily living

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Symptoms without significant weight loss (less than 5 percent)

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Symptoms without significant weight loss (less than 5 percent)
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Symptoms without significant weight loss (less than 5 percent)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

Concepts.definition: The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff.

Concepts.longName: NIH Consensus Response Criteria for Chronic GVHD
Concepts.definition: A tool used to assess response to therapy for chronic Graft versus Host Disease (cGVHD) based on clinical trial findings and recommended by the NIH Chronic Graft-versus-Host Disease Consensus Response Criteria Working Group. The criteria were established in 2005 (Biol Blood Marrow Transplant, 12 (2006), pp. 252-266) and revised in 2014 (Biol Blood Marrow Transplant, 21 (2015), pp. 984-999).
Used of the degree of something undesirable e.g. pain or weather; also, strictness.
A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.
